tasks.title: Initialize Project Structure and Dependencies
tasks.description: Set up the npm project with proper configuration, create the basic file structure, and install necessary dependencies.
tasks.details:
1. Create a new directory for the project
2. Initialize npm project: `npm init -y`
3. Create the following directory structure:
   - src/
   - src/js/
   - src/css/
4. Install http-server: `npm install --save-dev http-server`
5. Configure package.json with scripts:
   ```json
   "scripts": {
     "serve": "http-server src -p 8080 --cors"
   }
   ```
6. Install FHIR client library: `npm install fhirclient`
7. Create basic HTML files:
   - src/launch.html (SMART launch entry point)
   - src/index.html (main application page)
8. Add .gitignore file for node_modules and other build artifacts
tasks.testStrategy: Verify project structure is correctly set up by running `npm run serve` and confirming the server starts on http://127.0.0.1:8080/. Check that all directories exist and package.json contains correct configuration.

subtasks.title: Install and configure development dependencies
subtasks.description: Install the http-server for local development and configure package.json scripts.
subtasks.details:
1. Install http-server as a development dependency:
   `npm install --save-dev http-server`
2. Open package.json and update the scripts section:

   }

subtasks.testStrategy: Run `npm run serve` and confirm the server starts successfully on http://127.0.0.1:8080/.

subtasks.title: Install FHIR client library

subtasks.details:
1. Install the FHIR client library:

2. Create a src/js/lib directory

4. Verify the library is correctly installed by checking package.json dependencies.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify that fhirclient is listed in package.json dependencies and the library file is accessible in the src/js/lib directory.

tasks.title: Implement SMART Launch HTML Entry Point
tasks.description: Create the launch.html entry point that initiates the SMART on FHIR launch sequence and handles the redirect to the authorization server.
tasks.details:
1. Create launch.html with basic HTML structure
2. Add FHIR client library script
3. Implement launch sequence using SMART JS client:
   ```javascript
   // src/launch.html
   <!DOCTYPE html>
   <html lang="en">
   <head>
     <meta charset="UTF-8">
     <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
     <title>SMART on FHIR Launch</title>
     <script src="./node_modules/fhirclient/build/fhirclient.js"></script>
   </head>
   <body>
     <script>
       // Initiate the SMART authorization sequence
       FHIR.oauth2.authorize({
         clientId: 'my_app',
         scope: 'launch patient/*.read',
         redirectUri: 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/index.html',
         completeInTarget: true
       });
     </script>
   </body>
   </html>
   ```
4. Ensure the launch URL parameters are properly handled
5. Test with the provided launch URL in the PRD
tasks.testStrategy: Test the launch sequence by accessing the provided launch URL: http://127.0.0.1:8080/launch.html?launch=eyJhIjoiMSJ9&iss=https%3A%2F%2Flaunch.smarthealthit.org%2Fv%2Fr4%2Ffhir. Verify that it redirects to the authorization server and handles the OAuth2 flow initiation correctly.

subtasks.title: Implement Secure Token Storage
subtasks.description: Add functionality to securely store authentication tokens using browser sessionStorage and implement token refresh capabilities.
subtasks.details:
Create functions in auth.js to handle token storage in sessionStorage. Implement saveToken(token) and getToken() functions. Add a checkTokenExpiration() function that verifies if the current token is still valid based on its expiration time. Implement a refreshToken() function that can obtain a new token when the current one expires. Ensure all token operations are performed securely and handle edge cases like missing or corrupted tokens.
<info added on 2025-07-25T12:16:48.932Z>
Enhanced auth.js module with comprehensive security improvements for token management:

1. Implemented selective token storage - only storing essential token data in sessionStorage while excluding sensitive information
2. Added token structure validation to verify integrity before use
3. Implemented token expiration checks with configurable refresh thresholds (refreshing tokens when they're within 5 minutes of expiration)
4. Added functionality to recreate FHIR client instances from stored tokens
5. Implemented automatic detection and clearing of invalid/corrupted tokens
6. Added comprehensive error handling with user-friendly messages for various OAuth2 scenarios:
   - Invalid token format
   - Token expiration
   - Refresh token failures
   - Network connectivity issues during token operations
   - Authorization server unavailability
   - Invalid client credentials
7. Added logging for token lifecycle events while ensuring no sensitive data is exposed in logs
</info added on 2025-07-25T12:16:48.932Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Test token storage by authenticating and verifying tokens are correctly saved in sessionStorage. Test token retrieval and check that expired tokens trigger the refresh flow correctly.

subtasks.title: Implement the main application script (app.js)
subtasks.description: Create the main application script that orchestrates the application flow, including authentication, patient context retrieval, and allergy data fetching.
subtasks.details: Create app.js in the src/js directory. Implement a DOMContentLoaded event listener that handles the application initialization flow: 1) Call handleAuth() to authenticate with FHIR server, 2) Call getPatientContext() to retrieve patient information, 3) Display patient name in the patient-info element, 4) Call getAllergyData() to fetch allergy information, 5) Hide the loading indicator, 6) Handle the case when no allergies are found, 7) Display allergy data using displayJsonData(). Wrap everything in try/catch to handle errors appropriately.

subtasks.title: Implement responsive design

subtasks.details: Add media queries to styles.css to handle different screen sizes. For small screens (max-width: 600px), adjust container padding, reduce font sizes, and modify margins for better mobile viewing. For medium screens (max-width: 900px), adjust layout proportions. Ensure content containers have max-width properties and use relative units (%, em, rem) instead of fixed pixel values where appropriate. Add responsive table styles for better display of data on small screens.

tasks.title: Create Documentation and Deployment Instructions
tasks.description: Develop comprehensive documentation including setup instructions, usage guide, and known limitations.
tasks.details:
1. Create a README.md file with the following sections:
   ```markdown
   # GigaTECH SMART on FHIR Allergy Display Application
   
   ## Overview
   This browser-based JavaScript application integrates with Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems using the SMART on FHIR framework to display patient allergy information.
   
   ## Setup Instructions
   
   ### Prerequisites
   - Node.js (v14 or higher)
   - npm (v6 or higher)
   
   ### Installation
   1. Clone this repository
   2. Install dependencies: `npm install`
   3. Start the development server: `npm run serve`
   
   ### Testing
   The application will be available at http://127.0.0.1:8080/
   
   To test with the SMART on FHIR sandbox, use the following launch URL:
   http://127.0.0.1:8080/launch.html?launch=eyJhIjoiMSJ9&iss=https%3A%2F%2Flaunch.smarthealthit.org%2Fv%2Fr4%2Ffhir
   
   ## Usage Guide
   1. Access the launch URL from within an EHR or using the test URL above
   2. The application will handle the SMART launch sequence automatically
   3. Authenticate with your EHR credentials when prompted
   4. The application will display the patient's allergy information in JSON format
   
   ## Technical Details
   - FHIR Version: R4
   - Authentication: SMART on FHIR OAuth2
   - Data Retrieval: AllergyIntolerance resources
   
   ## Known Limitations
   - Displays raw JSON data rather than a formatted human-readable view
   - Limited error recovery for certain edge cases
   - No offline mode support
   
   ## License
   [Specify license information]
   ```

2. Create a CONTRIBUTING.md file with development guidelines
3. Add inline code documentation with JSDoc comments
4. Create a simple user guide with screenshots
5. Document testing procedures and results
6. Include troubleshooting section for common issues
tasks.testStrategy: Review documentation for accuracy and completeness. Verify that setup instructions work correctly by following them on a clean system. Check that all features and limitations are properly documented.
